titleStmt.title: The Description of an Irish Feast translated almost literally out of the Original Irish in the Year 1720.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: 12 Irish lines (written in 11 lines) precede O Rork's noble Fare will ne'er be forgot,by those who were there, or those who were not.
His Revells to keep, we sup and we dine,On Seven Score Sheep, fat Bullocks and Swine.
Usquebagh to our Feast, in Pails was brought up.an hundred at least, and a 1wooden vessell Madder our Cup.
O there is the Sport, we rise with the Lightin disorderly Sort, from Snoring all Night.
Oh how was I trickt. my Pipe it was brokemy Pocket was pick't. I lost my new Cloak
I'm rifled, quoth Nell, of Mantle and Kerchiefwhy then fare them well, the De'ill take the Searcher
Come Harper, strike up, but first by your FavourBoy, giblot us a Cup, ay, this has Some Savour.
O Rourk's jolly Boys. ne'er dreamt of the Matter'till rous'd by the Noise. and musicall Clatter
They bounce from their Nest. no longer will tarrythey rise ready drest. without one Ave-Mary.
They dance in a round. cuting Capers and rampinga Mercy the Ground. did not burst with their Stamping
The Floor is all wet. with Leaps and with Jumpswhile the Water and Sweat. Splish Splash in their Pumps
Bless you late and early. Loughlen O Enakinby my hand you dance rarely. Margery Greenagan
Bring Straw for our bed. Shake it down to the Feetthen over us spread. the winnowing Sheet
To shew I don't flinch. fill the Bowl up againthen give us a Pinch. of your Sneezing, a Yean.
Good Lord, what a Sight. after all their good Chearfor People to fight. in the midst of their Beer:
They rise from their Feast. and hot are their Brainsa Cubit at least. the Length of their Skeans
What Stabs and what Cuts. what Clatt'ring of Stickswhat Strokes on Guts. what bastings and kicks!
With Cudgels of Oak. well harden'd in Flamean hundred heads broke. an hundred Struck lame
You Churl, I'll maintain. my Father built Luskthe Castle of Slane. and Carrick Drumrusk
The Earl of Kidare. and Moynalta his brotheras great as they are. I was nurs'd by their Mother
Ask that of old Madam. She'll tell you who's whoso far up as Adam. She knows it is true
Come down with that Beam. if Cudgells are Scarcea Blow on the Weam. and Kick on the A──se.
12 Irish lines follow244-007D
